thread.title: All Sydney grade cricket called off
thread.title_full: All Sydney grade cricket called off

title: All Sydney grade cricket called off
text:
Heat takes toll with all Sydney grade cricket at the weekend called off Ben Horne, The Daily Telegraph February 10, 2017 5:28pm 
FOR the first time in the history of Sydney grade cricket, all matches have been called off this weekend due to the extreme heat wave. 
Cricket Australia and NSW doctor John Orchard pushed strongly for the unprecedented step to be taken, and NSW Cricket has advised all associations to follow suit and cancel junior and senior matches. 
Dr Orchard was concerned at the risks grade cricketers would be exposed to on a day where temperatures are expected to soar into the mid-40s, with far less player support and medical services available to local cricketers at park grounds across the city than in the big leagues of Sheffield Shield cricket. 
Since Sydney grade cricket was launched way back in 1893, never before has a round of matches been called off due to heat. media_camera Action from Manly v St. George in Sydney grade cricket at the weekend. 
NSW chief executive Andrew Jones said the decision was not made lightly, but the advice of Orchard was hard to ignore. 
“My main concern is that grade cricket does not have the infrastructure in place to safely monitor and manage heat stroke in what is essentially an amateur volunteer-run organisation,” said Orchard. 
“At the SCG we have medical staff in place that will be monitoring players who are showing any signs of symptoms and making sure no one with heat stress returns to play. We also checked before the game that no one had pre-existing illness.” 
NSW and Queensland Shield players at the SCG have agreed upon drinks breaks every 40 minutes, rather than every hour, and Dr Orchard was running out to the middle during these breaks to monitor the condition of players. 
Cricket NSW doesn’t have jurisdiction over local cricket, but hopes individual associations will follow their lead in exercising caution. 
Country and regional competitions are being asked to make decisions based on weather conditions in their local areas. 
“We want men and women, girls and boys, to play as much cricket as possible however duty of care comes first,” said Jones. 
“If there are any concerns about the safety and wellbeing of players and umpires the association should take the sensible approach and cancel play on Saturday.”
